title: Ali Mustafa (footballer)
text:
Mohammad Ali bin Haji Mustafa is a <a href="Brunei">Brunei</a>an former national <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and current <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29%23Association%20football">coach</a>.
Ali was a midfielder for the <a href="Brunei%20%28Malaysia%20Premier%20League%20team%29">Bruneian representative team</a> than played in the <a href="M-League%20System">Malaysian leagues</a> in the mid-90s. He served as backup to the likes of <a href="Sadiy%20Abdullah%20Tujoh">Said Abdullah</a>, <a href="Rosli%20Liman">Rosli Liman</a> and <a href="Rosaidi%20Kamis">Rosaidi Kamis</a>.
After earning his coaching badges, Ali became head coach of new <a href="Brunei%20Premier%20League">B-League</a> side <a href="QAF%20FC">QAF FC</a> in 2003. His tenure lasted more than a decade until his team left the <a href="Brunei%20Super%20League">Brunei Super League</a> in <a href="2015%20Brunei%20Super%20League">2015</a>, but not before lifting three straight titles from <a href="2005%E2%80%9306%20Brunei%20Premier%20League">2005-06</a> to <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Brunei%20Premier%20League">2009-10</a>. He subsequently found work with Brunei's governing body of football, <a href="National%20Football%20Association%20of%20Brunei%20Darussalam">NFABD</a>, as the coach of the national <a href="Brunei%20national%20under-15%20football%20team">under-15</a>s in 2015.
For the <a href="2016%20Brunei%20Premier%20League">2016 season</a>, Ali coaches the <a href="Brunei%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Tabuan U17</a> team in the <a href="Brunei%20Premier%20League">Brunei Premier League</a>. They replaced the <a href="Brunei%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Tabuan U18s</a> led by <a href="Kwon%20Oh-son">Kwon Oh-son</a> which became Tabuan U21 in the <a href="Brunei%20Super%20League">Brunei Super League</a>. He became assistant coach to <a href="Mike%20Wong%20Mun%20Heng">Mike Wong</a> in the full national team after the completion of the Premier League season.
In 2020, he was re-appointed as head coach of the <a href="Brunei%20national%20football%20team">Brunei national football team</a>, while still coaching <a href="Kasuka%20FC">Kasuka FC</a> at club level.
International career.
As was practice for Brunei's football association to send a club side for international tournaments at the time, due to QAF winning the domestic title in 2006 and 2010 Ali was appointed head coach of the <a href="Brunei%20national%20football%20team">Brunei national football team</a> for the two <a href="AFC%20Challenge%20Cup">AFC Challenge Cup</a> campaigns of <a href="2006%20AFC%20Challenge%20Cup">2006</a> and <a href="2010%20AFC%20Challenge%20Cup%20qualification">2009</a>. (Brunei sent <a href="DPMM%20FC">DPMM FC</a> for games held in 2008 but the club declined in 2009 due to the hectic <a href="2009%20S.League">S.League</a> schedule.) He only managed one win in 6 matches for the Wasps.
Personal life.
His son Khairul Alimin is a football player for <a href="Wijaya%20FC">Wijaya FC</a> who has represented Brunei at youth level.
